title: Why hasn't riot had a skin contest yet?
body:
There are so many amazing fan made skin ideas to the point where riot could, and should, totally have a player based contest where they rally up the best skins and let the community vote on which one they want in the game. So many amazing skins that haven't been fulfilled yet come to mind like:
http://i.imgur.com/kWmacqG.jpg
https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/cc/d3/73/ccd373d60c1fe6c4a986460ff77036c4.jpg
https://encrypted-tbn1.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSy0abtpTVN5iiOMCBhhjtHhNpduVaCt7pyR_BnPw6xsKvhE28L

and so many others that would be an amazing fit in league. This should seriously be a thing.

replies.body:
I guess the most immediate reason is that we could never guarantee that the winning skin would be made. There could be copyright issues, it could be inappropriate, it could run into unforeseen problems or just be not practical for a skin.

Recently we ran a voting competition for All-Stars which culminated in the player-vote for a Diana skin which is now in production. That was an interesting experiment in player involvement at a level we can plan around, but at the end of the day we have to see if it results in the best possible skin for Diana players. Personally my thought is that at all times we should be looking to maximise the player value we can put into each skin we make, and that won't necessarily be the case if we leave it up to an online competition to dictate our production.

While that covers some of the why, I think we _could _run a competition and that it would be very interesting and fun. Who knows what the future will bring? Never say never.

Finally you might like to know that we're always looking for great ideas and great artists. Plenty of skins grow from fan concepts. Also the artist of the 'Eclipse Leona', as well as the artist who did 'Daughter of the Sun Leona' and of the artists who worked on the 'Darkin Temple' all work on the skins team now!

i think the way to avoid copyright and inappropriate stuff, would be to have internal riot voting first to select 10-20 skin art concepts then send those out to the public to vote, that way you can control what can/will be made while also avoiding any copyright problems.

I love contests, I think they are a fun and interesting way of engaging with players. I entered into two of the art contests run in previous years before being hired by Riot. It's an awesome excuse to go all out on a piece of art and a way to feel like you're a part of something cool. I did see in those past contests an overwhelming amount of art produced to the point where it took a big chunk of Riot's time to go through thousands of entries. I also saw a lot of anger, frustration and negative comments when the winners were announced. There were a lot of professional artists in the competition because of the popularity of LoL and the huge prizes and I can understand why a lot of players were disenfranchised by the results. So I understand why they began moving away from those kind of contests.

I disagree about the assumptions that the majority of players would participate or that a winning skin concept would then sell well, there is no evidence to support that. It would be amazing if they did, but it's really not something to bank on. Ultimately our decisions are driven by one question; "Is this the best thing we can do for players with the time we have?" because, even if it's not a bad idea, if there is a better use of our time then it's hard to justify. The resources for a competition like that would really need to be justified, and that's why I think the All-Stars event was a good testing of the waters. So I want to see how 'Fire Diana' is received before I go pitching a community skin contest to my POs.

But all this thoughtful discussion is really helping balance the pros and cons and I still think it would be pretty fun >:)

It's how it's done for other games. Company releases a template and allows people to vote on the ones the art team approved.

I'd recommend taking a route similar to what WotC does for Magic's You Make the Card.
Say...
1. Open vote for the champion role to narrow down submissions.
2. Run off vote if there's a narrow margin of victory.
3. Have a period of open submission for skin concepts. (with all necessary legal things covered in that process)
4. Have people sift through and narrow down the designs to the best/most viable.
5. Pit submissions against each other. (For the most recent YMtC it was narrowed down to 8 and then single elimination)
6. Put together some splash art descriptions
7. Vote on those
8. Sketches based on art description
9. Vote on those
10. Open name submission (again, include legal stuff on the form)
11. Narrow down internally
12. Put up for vote
13. Make skin
14. Make players happy
15. Sell skin
16. ???
17. Profit

Something along those lines, the latter parts could probably be condensed down if necessary/desired.

I did initially think about YMtC, but making one card in a set that is sold as random packs of 15 (in a year where there are roughly 1000 cards printed) is quite different than making a stand-alone product that is one of only ~60. Another major difference is the size of the audience - it's almost impossible to run a competition with multiple stages simultaneously across all regions, handling translation and collation. And that's how we'd want to do it so all players can be involved. Another drawback is that these kind of competitions don't actually involve a lot of the community and thus don't provide that much value for players. The latest YMtC actually has "Designed by the Magic community" printed on it and I suspect it's because there was no way of knowing that the previous YMtCs were. Unless you were active on the website at that particular time, they are just another card. Even people who are active here on the boards often don't know about the All-Stars skin competition we just ran, and they're active on the site! An in-client event would work better, but that's not something we can easily implement until the LCU happens.

On the other hand, our boards already work as an informal voting system - where the most popular skin concepts make their way to the top and we see them. And while I'm sharing my thoughts about the challenges this idea faces I still think it would be fun to run this kind of competition in the future.
